items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond will be 4.85mAOD at 17:30 on 29/04/21 and 4.84mAOD at 05:45 on 30/04/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are peaking. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 43 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 12:00 on 30/04/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to autumn and winter rainfall and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom.
   
Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.

Although levels have declined during the last few weeks, we expect levels to remain high and low lying land and roads therefore remain at risk of flooding.
  
Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 
 
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 5 May or as the situation changes.

Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences at Porlock Weir with sea spray expected as a result of high tides and strong winds this evening and tomorrow morning. The first forecast high water is at 21:30 on 29/04/2021 with a level of 6.62 mAOD and a Force 4 north westerly wind. The second forecast high water is at 09:50 on 30/04/2021 with a level of 6.32 mAOD and a Force 4 north easterly wind. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point. For more detail please refer to local tide tables. Flooding to low lying land and roads is possible at this time. Conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tides. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and checking defences. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths. This message will be updated on 30/04/2021 or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood alert has been removed due to improving conditions

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected over the high tide of Thursday 29th April due to spring tides. Water levels will be high for up to 2 hours either side of the high tide which is at 20:45. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect coastal and tidal areas between Hartland Point and Lynmouth, including the Taw Torridge Estuary. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated as the situation changes.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the high tide level at Ilfracombe is 5.04m AOD at 20:45.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: High spring tides are forecast today and tomorrow. Forecast high water is at 22:00 on 29/04/21 with a level of 7.55 metres AOD and a Force 3 North Easterly wind. Second forecast high water is at 10:15 on 30/04/21 with a level of 7.24 metres AOD and a Force 3 Easterly wind. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth. Properties are unlikely to flood at this point but tides remain high although beginning to fall. There is a possibility of high water levels for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. Our incident response staff will be monitoring the situation and local flood gates remain closed. Be careful along beaches and low lying coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated Friday 30/04/2021.

High spring tides are forecast. Tides will be at their highest between 9:00am and 11:00am Friday morning 30/04/21, but these tides are expected to reach slightly lower than the peaks in recent days. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however these conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. 
This series of high tides will last until Friday 30/04/21. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. 
The tide peaked Thursday night 29/04/21 at Avonmouth Portbury at 7.58m & Newport at 7.17m. 
Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.3m to 7.5m at 10.15am Friday 30/04/21, Newport 6.9m to 7.1m at 10:15am Friday 30/4/21. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on Friday 30/04/21, or as the situation changes.

The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.  
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.
